Zinc(II) porphyrin-based ionic porous organic polymers (iPOPs) having abundant dual-function sites for promoting cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides Dan Wang Validation Visualization Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Linjing Ma Investigation Validation Visualization Data curation Methodology Dongping Wang Software Formal analysis Data curation Renhe Wang Visualization Data curation Software Ning Wang Supervision Project administration Resources ⁎ Jun Li Conceptualization Methodology Resources Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Natural Functional Molecule of the Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry & Materials Science, Northwest University, Xi’an 710069, China Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Natural Functional Molecule of the Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry & Materials Science, Northwest University Xi’an 710069 China Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Natural Functional Molecule of the Ministry of Education, College of Chemistry & Materials Science, Northwest University, Xi’an 710069, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. A series of zinc(II) porphyrin-based ionic porous organic polymers [ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40)] were synthesized by the free-radical copolymerization of pyridinium–functionalized Zinc(II) porphyrin (ZnTPyPBr4) and divinylbenzene (DVB) through solvothermal method and characterized successfully. The iPOPs had high specific surface areas, relative high CO2 adsorption capacity, abundant dual-function sites (Zn and Br-) and high catalytic efficiency for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions (80 ℃，0.5 MPa CO2). In particular, ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP displayed the highest catalytic activity with a conversion of 99 % for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epichlorohydrin, wide applicability for different epoxides and could be recycled five times with almost no loss of activity. Notably, the kinetic experiments demonstrate that ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP exhibited a low activation energy (22.64 kJ mol−1) for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epichlorohydrin in the absence of solvent and cocatalyst. Graphical Abstract A series of zinc(II) porphyrin-based ionic porous organic polymers [ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40)] were synthesized and characterized successfully. The iPOPs had abundant dual-function sites (Zn and Br-) and high catalytic efficiency for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions (80 ℃, 0.5 MPa CO2). The kinetic experiments demonstrate that ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP exhibited a low activation energy (22.64 kJ mol−1) for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epichlorohydrin in the absence of solvent and cocatalyst. ga1 Keywords CO2 cycloaddition Epoxides Zinc porphyrin Ionic porous organic polymer Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2), a common gas in the atmosphere, contributes to global warming and climate change owing to its increasing release caused by the large-scale combustion of fossil fuels and deforestation [1]. From another perspective, CO2 is regarded as a nontoxic, ubiquitous, non-flammable, inexpensive and sustainable C1 feedstock in the field of organic synthesis [2]. Therefore, the chemical conversion of CO2 is considered to be a very important strategy in mitigating the above problems [3,4]. In particular, the 100 % atom-economical cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxide has attracted considerable attention for latent applications of cyclic carbonate in lithium-ion batteries, polymer productions and the synthesis of fine chemicals [5,6]. Notably, major hurdles to the transformation of CO2 is its high thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertia, which means an effective catalyst is needed for the successful conversion [7]. In the past few years, numerous homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been developed for the cycloaddition, such as alkali metal salts [8], quaternary phosphonium salts [9,10], porous organic polymers (POPs)[11–13], metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) [14–16]. Compared with homogeneous catalyst, heterogeneous catalyst overcomes the impediment of separation of product and catalyst and is ease of recyclability. As a heterogeneous catalyst, porous organic polymers (POPs) composed of organic building units connected by covalent bonds are very popular in the field of catalysis, especially covalent organic frameworks (COFs) [17–20]. Specifically, POPs are promising catalysts in the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides for its hierarchical porous structure, high specific surface areas, adjustable organic functionalities and excellent stability [21]. Synchronously, among POPs, ionic porous organic polymers (iPOPs) exhibit effective catalytic activity owing to the combination of porous networks with charged characteristic [22–25]. More importantly, the bifunctional iPOPs for catalyzing CO2 cycloaddition can be synthesized by incorporating metal active sites and nucleophile into charged frame by appropriate strategies. For instance, recently, Liu et al. reported Lewis acid-base bifunctional pyridine-zinc-based ionic porous organic polymers (Py-Zn@IPOPX, X = Br, I, Ac) constructed by the Schiff base reaction and post-modification strategy, Py-Zn@IPOPI had good catalytic activity for cycloaddition of CO2 and propylene oxide under co-catalyst/ solvent-free conditions [26]. Particularly, owing to the structural designability, rich nitrogen atom and π conjugate structure of molecular, porphyrins are considered to be ideal substrates for the construction of bifunctional iPOPs by the combination of halogen ions introduced to the periphery of the porphyrin and coordinated metal in the center of the porphyrin [27–30]. At present, many porphyrin-based bifunctional iPOPs have been reported and proved that they had excellent catalytic activity for cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides [31–34]. Earlier this year, our group also reported a zinc(II) porphyrin-based ionic porous organic polymer (ZnTPyPBr4-iPOP) synthesized by free radical self-polymerization of ZnTPyPBr4, which exhibited excellent catalytic performance for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epichlorohydrin. However, the fly in the ointment is that the synthesis temperature of ZnTPyPBr4-iPOP was high (200 ℃) and the BET surface area was small (124.7 m2/g) [35]. Continuing our work, in order to further increase the specific surface area and improve the full contact between substrate and active center, to further achieve effective conversion under mild conditions, a series of zinc(II) porphyrin-based ionic porous organic polymers [ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40)] were prepared by the free-radical copolymerization of zinc porphyrin (ZnTPyPBr4) with divinylbenzene (DVB). The polymers had high specific surface areas, relative high CO2 adsorption capacity and abundant dual-function sites, showed good catalytic activity and excellent recyclability in the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions (80 ℃, 0.5 MPa CO2). 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and instruments All experimental reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without any further purification, except for H2TPyPBr4 and ZnTPyPBr4, which were synthesized by ourselves (See Scheme 1, Scheme S1 and Fig. S1, S2). Infrared spectra were taken on a BEQ UZNDX 550-FT-IR spectrophotometer (Bruker) with KBr pellets. Solid UV-Vis spectra were performed on a SHIMADZU UV-3600 plus UV-Vis spectrophotometer. UV-Vis spectra were obtained on a Shimadzu UV 1800 UV-Vis spectrophotometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were recorded on ZEISS SIGMA. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were observed on a FEI Talos F200X microscope. The surface chemical composition of the sample was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) on the UK Kratos Axis Ultra. The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were carried out at 77 K on TriStar II 3020 apparatus (Micromeritics) using nitrogen as the probing gas. CO2 sorption isotherms were performed at 273 K and 298 K using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 HD88 surface area instrument. The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded on a NETZSCH STA449C instrument from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in the airflow (20 mL min−1). The PXRD patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 diffractometer using graphite monochromatic copper radiation (Cu Kα) at 40 kV and 30 mA over the 2θ range from 10° to 60°. The zinc and bromine contents of the catalysts were determined by ICP-OES. 1H NMR spectra were recorded by the AVANCE III 400 MHz instrument. 2.2 Synthesis of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40) As can be seen in Scheme 1, take the synthesis of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP as an example: firstly, under nitrogen atmosphere, ZnTPyPBr4 (0.20 g, 0.14 mmol, the detailed synthetic procedures were introduced in Supporting information) was dissolved into 1 mL N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF), and then divinylbenzene (DVB, 0.53 g, 4.2 mmol) and azodiisobutyronitrile (initiator: AIBN, 73 mg, 10 wt%) were added successively. The solution was stirred on a magnetic stirrer for 30 min to blend well, and then was placed in a high-pressure reactor at 160 °C for 72 h. After the reaction, the dark green solid powder was obtained, which was washed by DMF for several times and purified by Soxhlet extraction with ethanol as solvent until the solution was colorless. Finally, the dark green powder ZnTPyPBr4/DVB (1:30)-iPOP (0.66 g, yield: 90 %) was obtained by vacuum drying for 8 h. The synthesis processes of other samples (ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 40)) were similar except that the initial feeding ratio of ZnTPyPBr4 and DVB. ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:10)-iPOP: ZnTPyPBr4 (0.20 g, 0.14 mmol), DVB(0.18 g, 1.4 mmol) and initiator AIBN (38 mg, 10 wt%); ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:20)-iPOP: ZnTPyPBr4 (0.20 g, 0.14 mmol), DVB(0.36 g, 2.8 mmol) and initiator AIBN (56 mg, 10 wt%); ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:40)-iPOP: ZnTPyPBr4 (0.20 g, 0.14 mmol), DVB(0.71 g, 1.4 mmol) and initiator AIBN (91 mg, 10 wt%). 2.3 Catalytic evaluation The cycloaddition of CO2 with epichlorohydrin (ECH) was used to evaluate the catalytic performance. The steps were as follows: firstly, the catalyst and epoxide with the required mass were accurately weighed respectively and added into the quartz glass tube successively, and then the magnetron was added. The quartz glass tube was placed in the magnetic agitator of the 50 mL stainless steel high-temperature and high-pressure reactor, then the reactor was tightly screwed, the CO2 gas cylinder was connected and CO2 was slowly poured into the reactor, and the reactor was left standing for a few minutes. Then the air and CO2 in the kettle were discharged, and the operation was repeated for three times. Finally, 0.5 MPa CO2 was filled into the sealing device, and the reaction temperature was set at 80 ℃. After the reaction, the reactor was first taken out and cooled to room temperature in an ice water bath, then the remaining CO2 in the reactor was slowly drained, the quartz glass tube was taken out, a small amount of trichloromethane was added into the reactor, mixed evenly, and centrifuged to obtain the supernatant. Then 30 μL supernatant was mixed evenly with 0.5 mL deuterium chloroform (CDCl3). 1H NMR was used to analyze the conversion and selectivity of the reaction. The procedure for testing the suitability range of substrate was the same as above, except the ECH was replaced with other epoxides. The experimental steps of recycling were as follows: after each reaction, the solid catalyst was recovered by simple centrifugation and washed three times with trichloromethane. The regenerated solid catalyst was vacuum dried at 60 ℃ for 4 h before entering the next catalytic cycle. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40) The FTIR spectra of DVB, ZnTPyPBr4 and all iPOPs was illustrated in Fig. 1. The strong stretching vibration absorption peak (1633 cm−1) of CC in olefinic bond appeared in the infrared spectra of DVB and ZnTPyPBr4 while the peak was not obvious in the infrared spectra of all iPOPs. However, all iPOPs showed strong stretching vibration absorption peak of C–H of methylene (–CH2–) at 2928 cm−1, which proved that ZnTPyPBr4 and DVB successfully copolymerized with high degree of polymerization. Furthermore, ZnTPyPBr4 and all iPOPs showed peaks at 992 cm−1 that is the characteristic peak of the N-M of metalloporphyrin, which confirms that the polymerized porphyrin was not destroyed. It is worth noting that for DVB, the strong peak at 989 cm−1 can be attributed to the out-of-plane rocking vibration of protons on olefin carbon (ω = CH). The UV–Vis solid-state spectra of the iPOPs were shown in Fig. 2. ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40) exhibited characteristics of metalloporphyrin with one Soret band around 425 nm and two Q bands around 558 and 623 nm, indicating that the molecular structure of zinc porphyrin did not change after polymerization. Notably, compared with ZnTPyPBr4 (Fig. S3), the absorption peak of Soret band of all iPOPs showed obvious blue shift (from 441 nm to 425 nm), which was caused by H-aggregates of ZnTPyPBr4 in iPOPs. The morphologies of all iPOPs were analyzed by SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. 3, SEM images of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP showed that the polymers were mainly composed of nano-sized small particles which were loosely deposited to form irregular lamellae aggregates with rough surfaces. TEM images of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP in Fig. 4 further indicated that the polymers were loosely composed of nanoparticles with many irregular hierarchical pores. In addition, the distribution of elements in ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP was determined by energy dispersive X-ray (EDS) spectroscopy in TEM, as shown in Fig. 4E, C, N, Zn and Br were uniformly distributed in the polymer, demonstrating the successful integration of ZnTPyPBr4 molecules into the polymer framework. The surface chemical composition of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP was further analyzed by XPS ( Fig. 5). Peaks corresponding to the C 1s, N 1s, Br 3d and Zn 2p levels were shown in the full XPS spectrum, indicating that these elements coexist in ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP. The peaks in the XPS spectrum of N 1s can be classified as photoelectron peak of nitrogen on pyrrole (399.2 eV) and pyridine cationic photoelectron peak (400.5 eV). The XPS spectrum of Zn 2p showed two peaks at the binding energy of 1022.5 eV and 1045.5 eV, corresponding to the characteristic photoelectron peaks of Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2, respectively, and the ratio of peak area between the two peaks was 1:2, which proves that Zn2+ was inserted into the porphyrin ring. The fine spectrum of Br 3d showed the characteristic photoelectron peak of Br at 69.1 eV. Moreover, the spectra of Zn 2p and Br 3d confirm the presence of both the Zn2+ active site and the nucleophile Br− active site in ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP. The structural characteristics of iPOPs were studied by nitrogen adsorption and desorption at 77 K. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms of all iPOPs were shown in Fig. 6A. Among them, the isotherms of these iPOPs were rapidly increased in the region with low relative pressure (P/P0 < 0.1), which was caused by the filling of micropores. While in the region with P/P0 > 0.4, the presence of hysteresis loops indicated the presence of mesopores, which displayed that the iPOPs had a graded porous property. As calculated by the NLDFT method, Fig. 6B showed that the pore size distribution of these iPOPs ranges from 0 nm to 38 nm, further confirming that all iPOPs contained hierarchical pore structures that facilitate the capture of CO2 and the diffusion of reactants and products in catalytic reactions. Notably, the BET surface area and pore volume increased as the ratio of ZnTPyPBr4 to DVB decreased (from 1:10 to 1:40), ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:10)-iPOP, ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:20)-iPOP, ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP and ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:40)-iPOP had large BET specific surface area with 389, 484, 663 and 693 m2 g−1 respectively and large pore volume with 0.30, 0.67, 0.87 and 1.23 cm3 g−1 respectively. At the same time, we can see that the micropores became less and less with the increase of the content of DVB from Fig. 6B, which demonstrated that DVB contributes to the formation of larger pores and the ratio of ZnTPyPBr4 to DVB has a significant effect on the pore structure of iPOPs. The abundant nitrogen atoms and porous structures in ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40) can effectively enhance the interaction between CO2 and polymer skeleton. Therefore, CO2 adsorption property of all iPOPs at 273 and 298 K was studied. As shown in Fig. 7A, all iPOPs display good CO2 uptake at 273 K (22.3–24.6 cm3 g−1) and 298 K (12.4–15.2 cm3 g−1), and show similar adsorption capacities for CO2 from the small difference of CO2 uptakes. Among the four iPOPs, the CO2 adsorption property of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:10)-iPOP and ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:40)-iPOP were relatively higher. Concretely, the high adsorption capacity of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:10)-iPOP is due to its most micropores and highest ZnTPyPBr4 content. However, the high adsorption capacity of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:40)-iPOP can be attribute to its largest pore volume. In addition, the CO2 isovolumetric adsorption enthalpy (Q st) of iPOPs were calculated by using Clausius–Clapeyron equation (Fig. 7B, Fig. S4–S6), and under low CO2 coverage, the Q st of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP was 26.1 kJ mol−1, indicating a strong physical interaction between CO2 and the polymer skeleton. In order to explore the thermal stability of heterogeneous catalyst iPOPs, thermogravimetric analysis was performed in N2 atmosphere to obtain its thermogravimetric curves. As can be seen from Fig. 8, all iPOPs samples had excellent thermal stability and significant weight loss occurred at 400 ℃, which may be caused by the decomposition of polymer skeleton. Heterogeneous catalyst iPOPs appeared a residual weight range of 21–40 wt% at 800 ℃, which was due to carbonization of sample, where different residual weights for iPOPs were attributed to their different Zn content and different degrees of crosslinking. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) images of all iPOPs were shown in Fig. S7. All iPOPs samples only showed a dispersion peak produced by amorphous SiO2 from slide glass (background) at 20.5–21.7°, and none of the iPOPs samples showed sharp strong peaks in other locations, which indicated that the iPOPs had amorphous structure. ICP-OES was used to determine the content of active sites (Zn and Br-) in the iPOPs, the data of all iPOPs was summarized in Table S1. As shown in Table S1, the measured values of the content of Zn2+ and Br- in all iPOPs were close to the theoretical values, indicating that these iPOPs had abundant bifunctional active sites, which was important for subsequent catalysis. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation Taking the heterogeneous catalyst ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP as an example, conditions of reactions with 80 ℃, 0.5 MPa CO2, without solvent and cocatalyst were mild. The effects of reaction time and the molar ratio of substrate to catalyst (S/C) on the catalytic activity for cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and ECH were investigated. Fig. 9 showed the effect of reaction time and [ECH]/ [Cat.](S/C) on the catalytic activity of cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and ECH. As can be seen from Fig. 9A, with the increase of reaction time, the conversion of ECH was higher, reaching 99 % in 18 h. However, when the reaction time continued to increase, the conversion of ECH almost did not change. Moreover, the selectivity of the product propylene chlorocarbonate was 99 %. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. 9B, when S/C decreased from 5000 to 500, the conversion of ECH increased from 30 % to 98 % owing to the increase of catalyst relative amount. Therefore, S/C = 500 was selected as the molar ratio of reaction. Using the reaction time (18 h), reaction temperature (80 ℃), CO2 pressure (0.5 MPa) and S/C (500) as the reaction conditions, the cycloaddition of CO2 and ECH was used the model. The catalytic properties of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40) were evaluated. The results of catalytic experiments were listed in Table 1. As can be seen from Table 1, basically, the conversion of all iPOPs reached more than 90 %, indicating that the four iPOPs had excellent catalytic performance. Meanwhile, the conversion of four iPOPs increased firstly and then decreased with the decrease of the ratio of ZnTPyPBr4 to DVB (from 1:10 to 1:40). When the ratio of ZnTPyPBr4 to DVB was 1:30, the conversion of ECH reached 99 % (Table 1, Entry 3), which may be the result of a combination of the specific surface area and the amount of exposed active sites. Specifically, although ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:10)-iPOP and ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:20)-iPOP have more exposed active sites than ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP and ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:40)-iPOP, the conversion of them were only 90 % and 92 %, respectively (Table 1, Entry 1, 2), which may attribute to their low BET surface area that hindered the diffusion of the reactant (CO2, ECH) in the heterogeneous catalyst. On the contrary, although ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:40)-iPOP have highest BET surface area, its conversion was lower than that of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP (Table 1, Entry 4) owing to the least amount of exposed active sites in the ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:40)-iPOP. The highest catalytic activity of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP may be the result of a relatively suitable ratio of ZnTPyPBr4 to DVB and a high BET specific surface area. These results indicated that both high BET surface area and suitable ratio between monomers are important for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides. Furthermore, ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP was compared with the reported heterogeneous catalyst that catalyzed cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and ECH in Table S2, which demonstrated ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP had excellent catalytic performance. For the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and ECH, the rate formula of the reaction kinetics equation was shown in Eq. (3.1). In the reaction process, due to the presence of excess CO2, the concentration of CO2 can be considered as a constant. In addition, the amount of catalyst was also fixed, so Eq. (3.1) can be simplified to Eq. (3.2). Because ECH and CO2 cycloaddition reactions were considered to be first order reactions, a= 1. x is the conversion of propylene chlorocarbonate after the reaction time t (h). Eq. (3.2) can be converted to Eq. (3.3). Eq. (3.4) can be obtained by integrating Eq. (3.3) from 0 to t. Therefore, the reaction rate constant k can be represented by the linear slope of linear fitting in Fig. 10A. As can be seen from Fig. 10A, the reaction rate constant k increased with the increase of temperature. According to Arrhenius' rule of thumb, the activation energy E a can be calculated from k at different temperatures as shown in Fig. 10A using Eq. (3.5), where T represents the absolute temperature (K), R is the universal gas constant (8.314 J mol−1 K−1), E a represents the activation energy (kJ mol−1). Moreover, the activation energy of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP was compared with those of other catalysts, as shown in Table 2. ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP exhibited a low activation energy (22.64 kJ mol−1) at a relatively low CO2 pressure (0.5 MPa) and without cocatalyst. The catalytic activities of heterogeneous catalyst ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP for different epoxides were explored. The results of catalytic activities were listed in Table 3. As can be seen from Table 3, ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP could effectively catalyze the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with different epoxides, and all had a high selectivity of 99 %. Among them, the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides with small molecular structure (such as propylene oxide and epoxybutane) showed efficient catalytic activity (conversion of 99 % and 94 %, respectively) (Table 3, Entry 1, 2). For the larger substrates, styrene oxide and glycidyl phenyl ether, ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP also showed conversion of 86 % and 88 %, respectively (Table 3, Entry 3, 4). To our surprise, the conversion still reached 54 % after 48 h for the reaction of CO2 with glycidyl phenyl ether at room temperature and 1 bar CO2 (Table 3, Entry 5), which shows the catalytic performance of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP was excellent. For allyl glycidyl ether, an epoxide with long alkyl side chain, the catalyst also effectively catalyzed its reaction with CO2 (79 %) (Table 3, Entry 6). Nevertheless, the conversion of the catalyst for cyclohexene oxide was only 9 % due to the high steric hindration which hindered the attack of the nucleophile (Br−), making it difficult for cyclohexene oxide to open ring, thus reducing the conversion. (Table 3, Entry 7). The recyclability of heterogeneous catalyst ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP was investigated. Since the catalyst was insoluble in general organic reagents, it can be recovered after each cycle by centrifugation, washing, and drying. Notably, the reaction conditions of cycle experiment were the same as the optimized conditions, except that the reaction time was reduced to 6 h from 18 h for making full use of the active centers of the catalyst during the reaction. In other words, it is difficult to evaluate the stability of catalyst under condition of 18 h because the active centers of the catalyst may not be fully utilized when the conversion reached 99 %. As can be seen in Fig. 11, the experimental results showed that the catalyst was used in 5 cycles, and the conversion of each cycle was kept at 70 %, and the selectivity was kept at 99 %, and there was almost no loss of activity of the catalyst after 5 cycles, which proved that the catalyst had high stability. The SEM images of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP before used and after 5 cycles (Fig. S8) demonstrated that there was almost no difference between the morphology of the cycled catalyst and that of the newly prepared sample. In addition, the FTIR spectra of ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP before used and after five cycles were consistent (Fig. S9), except the peak appeared at 1790 cm−1 after five cycles, which could be attributed to the stretching vibration of the CO of residual cyclic carbonate on the catalyst after five cycles. Furthermore, in order to further prove the stability of the catalyst, we tested the content of Zn2+ and Br- in ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP after five cycles, and the results showed that the content of Zn2+ and Br- were close to that of the fresh ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP (Table S3), without significant loss of active sites. The results indicated that ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP has excellent stability. 4 Conclusion In summary, four Zinc(II) porphyrin-based ionic porous organic polymers [ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40)] with ZnTPyPBr4 and DVB as monomer were prepared by solvothermal method by free radical copolymerization. These bifunctional ionic porous organic polymers had high specific surface areas, relative high CO2 adsorption capacity and abundant bifunctional active sites, which made them exhibited high catalytic activity in the reaction of CO2 cycloaddition to the corresponding cyclic carbonate. Among them, ZnTPyPBr4/DVB (1:30)-iPOP had good substrate applicability and recyclability under the condition of solvent-free and cocatalyst helpless. Therefore, the new efficient bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst is expected to be widely used in the chemical fixation of CO2 into cyclic carbonates. coredata.dc:description: A series of zinc(II) porphyrin-based ionic porous organic polymers [ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:m)-iPOP (m = 10, 20, 30, 40)] were synthesized by the free-radical copolymerization of pyridinium–functionalized Zinc(II) porphyrin (ZnTPyPBr4) and divinylbenzene (DVB) through solvothermal method and characterized successfully. The iPOPs had high specific surface areas, relative high CO2 adsorption capacity, abundant dual-function sites (Zn and Br-) and high catalytic efficiency for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions (80 ℃，0.5 MPa CO2). In particular, ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP displayed the highest catalytic activity with a conversion of 99 % for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epichlorohydrin, wide applicability for different epoxides and could be recycled five times with almost no loss of activity. Notably, the kinetic experiments demonstrate that ZnTPyPBr4/DVB(1:30)-iPOP exhibited a low activation energy (22.64 kJ mol−1) for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and epichlorohydrin in the absence of solvent and cocatalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Zinc(II) porphyrin-based ionic porous organic polymers (iPOPs) having abundant dual-function sites for promoting cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides
